channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: Lithuania Welcomes Belarusians as It Rebuffs Middle Easterners
item.description: People fleeing repression in Belarus are processed quickly and given visas. Middle Eastern migrants passing through Belarus to the E.U. face a harsher fate.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aleksandr Dobriyanik, center, and his partner, Olga Ageyeva, right, fled the crackdown in Belarus and found refuge in a shelter for Belarusians in Vilnius, Lithuania.

item.title: Contending With the Pandemic, Wealthy Nations Wage Global Battle for Migrants
item.description: Covid kept many people in place. Now several developed countries, facing aging labor forces and worker shortages, are racing to recruit, train and integrate foreigners.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A teacher showing immigrant trainees how to weld at Bildungskreis Handwerk, a regional training hub in Dortmund, Germany.

item.title: Italy Frees Convicted Killer of U.K. Student Meredith Kercher
item.description: Rudy Guede had served 13 years of a 16-year sentence for the 2007 murder. Another student, Amanda Knox, was eventually exonerated in what became a polarizing case.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Rudy Guede, right, at a hearing in 2009 in Perugia, Italy.

item.title: In Venezuela’s Flawed Vote, Maduro Shows One Way to Retain Power
item.description: European observers said the elections were neither free nor fair. They showed how President Nicolás Maduro’s government, however unpopular, can win by excluding and splitting opponents.
item.dc:creator: Isayen Herrera and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Only 42 percent of Venezuelan voters cast ballots in Sunday’s elections.

item.title: As Virus Cases Rise in Europe, an Economic Toll Returns
item.description: A series of restrictions, including a lockdown in Austria, is expected to put a brake on economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Georg Hochmuth/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Vienna decorated for Christmas. Austria is mandating vaccinations and imposed a nationwide lockdown on Monday.

item.title: Raids on Independent Groups in El Salvador Raise Fears of Repression
item.description: President Nayib Bukele bills himself as a young reformer, but a crackdown on voices outside the government’s control is fueling claims of growing authoritarianism.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Avelar and Oscar Lopez
item.media:description: Salvador’s president, Nayib Bukele, speaking in San Salvador in February.

item.title: Bulgaria Bus Crash Kills Dozens
item.description: The bus, which had Macedonian plates, caught fire on a highway on the way back from a trip to Istanbul, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Boryana Dzhambazova and Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:description: The accident happened near the village of Bosnek, in western Bulgaria, on Tuesday. Seven survivors with burns and lacerations, including a teenage girl, were taken to a hospital in Sofia, the country’s capital.

item.title: Hong Kong’s National Security Law Explained
item.description: Tony Chung, a 20-year-old student activist, is the youngest to be sent to prison under the harsh and expansive new security law passed in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Police officers standing guard outside a court in Hong Kong in July, after the first sentencing under the National Security Law.

item.title: Chun Doo-hwan, South Korea's Most Vilified Ex-Military Dictator, Dies at 90
item.description: The country’s most vilified former military dictator, he seized power in a coup and ruled his country with an iron fist for most of the 1980s.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Mr. Chun in 1978. Unapologetic to the end, he was the last to die among South Korea’s three military general-turned presidents.

item.title: New Zealand Plans to Reopen to International Visitors
item.description: Emerging from one of the world’s longest lockdowns, the country plans to admit most fully vaccinated travelers by the end of April without a mandatory hotel quarantine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: New Zealand has announced it will reopen to the world in coming months.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Europe’s economic toll.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Georg Hochmuth/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Vienna decorated for Christmas. Austria is mandating vaccinations and imposed a nationwide lockdown.

item.title: Buffalo Officials Reimpose a Mask Mandate as Cases Surge
item.description: Cases have doubled in Erie County over four weeks, prompting the return of a mask requirement for stores, restaurants, bars, salons, and other public indoor spaces.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.media:credit: Libby March for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cars waiting to enter a drive-through coronavirus testing site in Buffalo, N.Y., last year.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Nations scramble to attract migrant workers.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: A teacher showing immigrant trainees how to weld at Bildungskreis Handwerk, a regional training hub in Dortmund, Germany.

item.title: Europe’s Covid Death Toll Could Exceed 2 Million by Spring
item.description: Covid is now the leading cause of death in Europe, the World Health Organization said in a statement, with almost 4,200 new deaths a day, double the number at the end of September.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: A Ukrainian Orthodox priest performing a funeral service for someone who died of Covid at a cemetery in Kakhovka, Ukraine, in October.

item.title: This Ink Is Alive and Made Entirely of Microbes
item.description: Scientists have created a bacterial ink that reproduces itself and can be 3D-printed into living architecture.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Imbler

item.title: The U.S. Asks Court to Unblock Biden Vaccine Mandate for Big Companies
item.description: The ruling being appealed was issued by a three-judge panel on the Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Alisha Jucevic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pfizer vaccines being prepared at a mobile vaccine clinic in McMinnville, Ore., in October.

item.title: India's Arrest of Kashmiri Activist, Khurram Parvez, Is Criticized
item.description: Khurram Parvez’s detention has deepened concerns that the Modi administration is abusing the law to squelch dissent.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society
item.media:description: Khurram Parvez, left, of the Jammu Kashmir Coalition of Civil Society, which publishes reports on human rights abuses in the region, in 2020.

item.title: South Korea Links Over 200 Covid Cases to Religious Settlement
item.description: Nearly half of the residents at the facility in the city of Cheonan tested positive for Covid, an outbreak that comes as South Korea’s case levels surge.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: People wearing face masks on a street in Seoul last week.

item.title: Biden to Tap Into U.S. Oil Reserves to Combat Rising Gas Prices
item.description: In an attempt to reduce energy prices, the U.S. will release 50 million barrels of crude. Five other nations also will dip into stockpiles.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Stanley Reed and Jim Tankersley
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:description: Part of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve in Freeport, Texas. President Biden announced the release of 50 million barrels of crude oil, but traders did not seem impressed.

item.title: The Latest Covid Surge
item.description: And how to make sense of it.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers in Houston.

item.title: As Virus Cases Rise in Europe, an Economic Toll Returns
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: People walking past the closed Christmas market next to Stephen’s Cathedral, normally packed with crowds, in Vienna on Monday.

item.title: Are airlines ready for the holiday crush?
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Travelers walking through Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport on Monday.

item.title: It’s Never Too Late to Pick Up Your Life and Move to Italy
item.description: Holly Herrmann vowed to move to Italy when she was 20. Her dream came true 38 years later.
item.dc:creator: Alix Strauss
item.media:credit: Alessandro Grassani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Holly Herrmann and her husband, Jim, on their apartment balcony in Padua, Italy.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Europe’s fourth coronavirus wave.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: While most stores in Salzburg, Austria, closed on the first day of the nationwide lockdown, shops for essential daily needs, such as supermarkets and pharmacies, remain open.

item.title: 2 Canadian Journalists Arrested at Indigenous Protest Are Freed on Bail
item.description: Journalist groups denounced the arrest of a photographer and a filmmaker covering an Indigenous pipeline protest in British Columbia.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph taken in 2019 by Amber Bracken while on assignment for The New York Times showed a confrontation between the police and Indigenous activists in British Columbia.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Austria entered a nationwide lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: The streets of Salzburg were empty on Monday as Austria enters another coronavirus lockdown.

item.title: How Fake News on Facebook Helped Fuel a Border Crisis in Europe
item.description: Social media worsened a migrant crisis on the border of Belarus and Poland and helped smugglers profit off desperate people trying to reach Europe.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins, Adam Satariano and Jane Arraf
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants at a warehouse shelter in Bruzgi, Belarus, on Friday. Fake news about the situation on the border has saturated social media, particularly Facebook, during the crisis.

item.title: Trying to Blur Memories of the Gulag, Russia Targets a Rights Group
item.description: Prosecutors are trying to shut down Memorial International, Russia’s most prominent human rights group, as the Kremlin moves to control the historical narrative of the Soviet Union.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Members of the human rights group Memorial International held a press conference in their offices in Moscow last week.

item.title: Austria Imposes Lockdown Amid Europe’s Covid Surge
item.description: Europe is again at the center of the pandemic, and amid vaccine resistance and protests, nations are imposing new rules and pressuring people to get inoculated.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Salzburg, Austria, on Monday. The country went into its fourth nationwide lockdown and will make Covid-19 vaccines compulsory.

item.title: Critical Witness Testifies at Netanyahu Trial, Reviving a Drifting Case
item.description: Nir Hefetz, a former spokesman for Benjamin Netanyahu, is a state witness at the former prime minister’s corruption trial, which was once at the heart of a constitutional crisis.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Nir Hefetz, a onetime spokesman for Benjamin Netanyahu, the former prime minister of Israel, outside a court house last week in Jerusalem.

item.title: Unrest over vaccine mandates and economic inequality rocks Guadeloupe.
item.description: Demonstrations started with pickets of at a hospital on the main island, a French overseas department, and grew violent over the weekend. Protesters burned cars, looted businesses and clashed with riot police.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Violent demonstrations broke out in Pointe-à-Pitre, Guadeloupe, over the weekend.

item.title: Pfizer Vaccine Supplies Dwindle in Germany
item.description: A strong fourth Covid wave has led to a renewed run on vaccines.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Administering a booster vaccination this month in Frankfurt.

item.title: Kenya to Impose Restrictions on the Unvaccinated
item.description: The move, which will begin Dec. 21, is part of an effort to push more people to get inoculated and curb the spread of the virus.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Waiting to receive a shot of a vaccine in Nairobi, Kenya’s capital, in July.

item.title: Some Pacific Nations Won't Vaccinate Populations for Years, Research Predicts
item.description: Papua New Guinea will have vaccinated only a third of its adult population by 2026 if it continues at its current rate, according to an Australian think tank.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:description: A nurse prepared beds for new patients at a makeshift Covid-19 hospital in Port Moresby, Papua New Guinea, in October.

item.title: The Politics of Menace
item.description: Despite a congressman’s censure, Republicans have shown a growing tolerance for violent rhetoric.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paul Gosar shortly before his censure last week.

item.title: How Peng Shuai Went From ‘Chinese Princess’ to Silenced #MeToo Accuser
item.description: The tennis star won independence while remaining in Beijing’s good graces. But she has been unable to break through China’s resistance to sexual assault allegations.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peng Shuai during her qualifying match against Nicole Gibbs at U.S.T.A. Billie Jean King National Tennis Center in New York in 2019.

item.title: Australia Will Allow Some Visa Holders to Return in December.
item.description: The country will allow skilled workers and international students to enter next month, the government announced.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Passengers of a Singapore Airlines flight arriving at Melbourne International Airport on Sunday.

item.title: Limping and Penniless, Iraqis Deported From Belarus Face Bleak Futures
item.description: Hundreds of desperate Iraqis are being sent home after becoming political pawns in Belarus’s quarrel with its European Union neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf and Sangar Khaleel
item.media:credit: Hawre Khalid for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nazar Shamsaldin on Sunday with some of his family back in Erbil, Iraq, after being deported from Belarus.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: The reinstatement of Sudan’s prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Sudan Transitional Sovereign Council, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Abdalla Hamdok of Sudan, who was detained for weeks after a military coup on Oct. 25, returned to power under a deal with Lt. Gen. Abdel Fattah al-Burhan, the army chief.

item.title: As Hopes for Nuclear Deal Fade, Iran Rebuilds and Risks Grow
item.description: With Iran’s new administration preparing for its first international nuclear negotiations, there are signs that there will be no going back to the 2015 agreement.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Steven Erlanger, Farnaz Fassihi and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: For the first time since President Ebrahim Raisi took office in August, Iranian negotiators plan to meet with their European, Chinese and Russian counterparts to discuss the future of a nuclear agreement.

item.title: Angry and Divided, Austrians Argue Over a Lockdown and Vaccine Mandates
item.description: As a new wave of Covid infections spreads over Europe, resistance to public health measures is growing, and not just in Austria.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Protesters burned face masks during the Vienna demonstration.

item.title: Two of 17 Kidnapped Missionaries in Haiti Are Freed, Group Says
item.description: After being held hostage for 37 days by a gang, two people with a U.S. Christian aid group have been released in Port-au-Prince and are described as “safe.”
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Christian Aid Ministries compound in Titanyen, north of Port-au-Prince. Seventeen people affiliated with the group were held hostage.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Sudan’s military releases the prime minister.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

item.title: Playwright Is in Exile as Cuba Uses an Old Playbook to Quash Dissent
item.description: Yunior García, a rising star of the Cuban protest movement, fled to Spain. He is one of a young generation of artists who say they have chosen exile over imprisonment.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey
item.media:credit: Ben Roberts for The New York Times
item.media:description: The harassment of Yunior García began with decapitated pigeons left on his doorstep.

item.title: Ardeshir Zahedi, Irrepressible Iranian Diplomat, Dies at 93
item.description: While he enabled business deals worth billions of dollars, he also hosted lavish parties, led conga lines through his embassy and dated Elizabeth Taylor.
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:description: Ardeshir Zahedi, left, with Barbra Streisand and the producer Jon Peters at a reception at the Iranian Embassy in Washington in 1975. While serving as Iran’s ambassador to the United States in the 1970s, Mr. Zahedi was known for his extravagant parties and for a wide social orbit that embraced Ms. Streisand and numerous other celebrities.

item.title: Michigan Hospitals Struggle With Covid Surge
item.description: Staffing shortages and pandemic fatigue add to complications.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Nic Antaya for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ashtin Kubec, an emergency room nurse at the MidMichigan Medical Center in Alma, Mich., on Saturday. Many hospitals in the state are nearing their capacities from a surge in Covid patients.

item.title: British Columbia's Flooding Is Worse Because of Climate Change
item.description: After a summer of deadly heat and uncontrolled wildfires, British Columbia was hit by record rainfalls that forced the evacuation of towns and destroyed highways and rail lines.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Flooding last week in the Sumas Prairie area of Abbotsford, British Columbia.

item.title: As Pandemic Evictions Rise, Spaniards Declare ‘War’ on Wall Street Landlords
item.description: Protesters in Barcelona are pushing back against foreign investment firms that have bought up thousands of homes over the past decade and are forcing out residents who can’t pay the rent.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey and Roser Toll Pifarré
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family scheduled for eviction waiting outside their home, owned by Cerberus, in Piera, near Barcelona, Spain, this month. A court eventually delayed the eviction by a month.

item.title: More Asian Countries Slowly Reopen to Fully Vaccinated Travelers
item.description: The easing of restrictions comes as the holiday travel season is about to begin.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: It was time for a selfie at Marina Bay in Singapore this week as parts of Asia open up to visitors who are vaccinated.

item.title: Israeli Is Killed by Palestinian Near Holiest Site in Jerusalem
item.description: The shooting, the first attack by a Palestinian since May to result in the death of a Jewish civilian, could deepen tensions within Israel’s fragile governing coalition.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Myra Noveck
item.media:description: Israeli security officers removed a body from the scene of the attack in Jerusalem’s Old City on Sunday.

item.title: Chileans Will Vote For President on Sunday
item.description: The top contenders to lead Chile out of a turbulent era are a leftist 35-year-old former student activist and a 55-year-old far-right former congressman, offering voters a stark choice.
item.dc:creator: Pascale Bonnefoy and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: A polling station in Santiago, Chile, on Sunday.

item.title: In Hard Times, Afghan Farmers Are Turning to Opium for Security
item.description: The war’s intense conclusion and a drought combined to wipe out the famous Afghan pomegranate harvest in Kandahar Province, during a devastating national economic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Taimoor Shah
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Farmers harvesting opium from poppies this month in Maiwand, Afghanistan.

item.title: Rolling Deep: South Korean Youth Roam the City in Hair Curlers
item.description: The young South Korean women who wear them say they are not only functional, but also a sign of shifting ideas about beauty and a reflection of the country’s generational divide.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hair rollers in public are not an uncommon sight on the streets of Seoul. “You only have to look good in front of the people you care about,” one frequent curler-wearer explained.

item.title: How the U.S. Lost Ground to China in the Contest for Clean Energy
item.description: Americans failed to safeguard decades of diplomatic and financial investments in Congo, where the world’s largest supply of cobalt is controlled by Chinese companies backed by Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton, Dionne Searcey and Ashley Gilbertson
